comments.commentBody:
ESAI as pie...speaking of, who wouldn't like some KEYS LIMB pie? Or maybe some chocolate MOUSSE?

Thank you Mr. Raymon, for a fun, tasty Wed. XWord!
This is a truly heartrending story. I hardly know what to say. I pray you have prevailed.

The last time I saw my mother was three days after my fifth birthday. We were shopping when a policeman appeared, arrested her and drove us to the station. The police took me from her, and I never saw her again. My father acted as if she'd never existed, as if nothing had happened to me. The woman he hired to be our housekeeper I called the Wicked Witch, though I never told my father of her cruelties. Perhaps I feared he didn't care.

Only in the last decade (I'm 58) have I admitted how awful my childhood was, how I'd have given anything to have had my mother back. I refused my pain, because unlike so many others who have commented, it was invisible. Our town acted as if my mother had never existed. The wife of a prominent surgeon and World War II veteran, she broke the rules by not pretending all was well. She couldn't bear (this is conjecture on my part) his silence, his detachment, his workaholism. Like many spouses of veterans, she manifested the fallout of the war's trauma. Her depression and alcoholism became too severe to hide.

No one, not even her sisters, nor my brother, ever told me what happened to her. I do know she was institutionalized for a while. Long enough to scare her for good.

Yes, the hole is enormous and will never completely heal. I spent too many years living in trauma's grip, too many years with no tenderness, reassurance. A mother anchors a child to the earth. I pray I have prevailed and anchored my sons. They and my husband grace my life.

Excellent comment. I think throughout the conflict, the North's chief vulnerability was the potential for a loss of political support for the war, which the New York draft riots epitomized. That was the principle goal of Lee's invasion. Longstreet was correct that the Army of Northern Virginia could and should have found ground of their own choosing and then fought a defensive battle that could have resulted in another Fredricksburg and a defeat for the Army of the Potomac, which would have enhanced Lee's goal of undermining support for the war. Of course, as a practical matter, the victory at Gettysburg boosted northern support for the war and bought more time for Winfield Scott's Anaconda Strategy to deprive the South of imported war material.  The victory at Vickburg had the result of isolating 3 southern states and depriving the southern armies of the essential war materiel, men, animals and rations, they could provide. That left it for Grant and Meade to fight the battles of 1864 which drove the ANV back to Richmond while Sherman destroyed the South's ability to supply its army.

@ David - not every topic needs to be a polemic on how we need to tax every form of income at the highest rate possible.

However, if you think it's correct to tax investment profits, then you may ask why the IRS does not people deduct investment losses as well. The do not.

With investments, the socializes the gains, and privatizes the losses as a matter of tax law. That's the day to experience investors. Just ask people whose investment and home values evaporated during the great recession.

You have forgotten one other segment of society that will be influenced by the legalization of prostitution, and that is, young women who need jobs. Making it acceptable for them to become prostitutes, in fact, encouraging them to, by having them sent out to interviews for various kinds of sex work, isn't sending the right message to society - to them.

It's okay for someone to speak from the perspective of middle class feminism, with a career, but if you were without a job and already feeling the pressure from various sources in society to do what women were meant to do, you might reconsider. I hope so.

It's just as likely the women took up with drugs in order to endure the kinds of things their job entailed.

And they don't end up dead because of the drugs, any more than it is because of the men they are involved with who have killed them.

The solution - give up sex.

In the town I was born, Stuttgart - Germany, there is a building in the inner city called the 'Drei-Farben-Haus' (the three colored house).
It is the city's 'legal' house of prostitution.
I don't know how the 'johns' are screened but somehow it has always been said that there was a concierge and the women were screened monthly for sexually transmitted diseases (this was even before AIDS), making things safer for both clients and prostitutes.
I guess it was a gray area of the law but it simply tried to deal with reality and make an impossible situation more save for both parties while eliminating the 'pimp' and all that is related to that relationship.
The city is offering a 'hotel' - the women are safe, they have mandatory health checks and so are their clients......

Case in point: Aileen Wuornos. A horrific childhood, gave birth at 13, a prostitute from age 15, often homeless, repeatedly beaten and raped by her clients.

Rather than take it any more - and possibly be killed by these men - she began to kill them instead.

And the government's solution? The death penalty.

So either the women suffer unspeakable brutality until their bodies are found bound in burlap on a beach, or, in Aileen's case, they fight back with their own inchoate brutality. Or they survive on the largess of their pimps and pushers, shoved here and there by the "justice" system, and die from disease or overdose, slashing or shooting, exhaustion or freezing in an alley or a gutter on the cold streets of a big city.

Either way, these women end up dead. This article misses the point in a very sad way that only perpetuates the lies we tell ourselves about our society and morality, our love of children and justice, and our compassion. If we were to decide to make these lies into truths, women wouldn't have to lead lives such as these women led or die the deaths these women died.

"The police rarely help them...they rarely take their disappearances seriously....As far as the authorities are concerned..."

Who are you talking about? What police? What authorities? There's a picture of 6 cops looking for something associated with this article.

You think you can just say that and people are going to believe you. No mention is made of what department, what authorities, never mind the problems of addressing crimes involving people who don't want to be named, found or associated in any way.

The NYT can do better than this broad brush cop bashing which many people will just buy. I hope you're book has more than just stories of unsubstantiated opinion. I'll pass thank you.

Prostitution is like gambling. Do we legalize it to make it safer and more honest while capitalizing on its tax potential, or do we continue to just say shame, shame? Would legalization allow for greater opportunities to offer help to those who wanted it? Would it remove income from organized crime? Would it help reduce health problems?
Would it help remove children from the trade?

I ask these questions because I am not sure of the answers. I don't want this to be a career choice for my students any more than I would want being a hit man for hire, even though some of the same economic arguments raised in the article could apply to that profession as well. Easy good money during an economic downturn.
Hollywood prettifies prostitution all the time.  Don't confuse movies with reality.

From the article:"The market doesn’t care if prostitution is right or wrong, empowering or exploitative."

The market is men - the men who use prostitutes.

Ergo...

I can comprehend the factors that drive some to choose this option. The question remains, what drives the killers to react in the manner they do? And how much of the deviance is derived from unlinking sex from love? (Which has obviously become more common since the advent of birth control, so much so that the suggestion may seem out of place).

Something has transformed the killers into monsters and I suspect the origin is rooted in a feeling of being defrauded of the significance and value of life, which is of course a result of the sexual act.

Rather than a justification, the above constitutes a call to return to basics. Society has lost many fundamental values and the aberration didn't initiate with these murders.

Clairette--

Bolger's mean, vacuous ad hominems would have gotten him banned over the HuffPo. It amazes me that the NYT tolerates them. Except, not really. His views accord with theirs.

They do have that responsibiity, indeed, but all too often will eagerly cast it aside in favor of money and powermongering.

"Patriotism is the last refuge of a scoundrel." - Samuel Johnson

"Patriotism is the virtue of the vicious." - Oscar Wilde

Remind you of anyone you know?
"Sadder still is that war is sometimes necessary."  This statement is not true.  Never has been and never will be.  War is never necessary.  It is a political choice.

How sad that young men (and now young women as well) sacrifice their lives in war. Sadder still is that war is sometimes necessary.

Our leaders have a deep responsibility NOT to lead us into the horror of war lightheartedly.

So many people just don't understand interest rates or percentages. Therefore, I suspect many of these investors heard about "buy low and sell high" and completely misunderstood what they ought to have been doing. If that is indeed the case, how can they be reassured?

Otherwise, I'm not sure I understand what in the world individuals were thinking by buying bonds that would be paying such a tiny return. I understand the motivation of insurance companies who had no real risk, but individuals, not at all.

Or Adam Lanza that received a marksmanship certificate from the NRA--not that he needed it.

@Kevin Brock

Legitimate rulers and legislators lose their authority when they act like tyrants. Just ask King Charles I or King George III.

Texas Peter,

I doubt if you can find anything good where the US is at the top of the rating skills. other than a few obscure sports that almost no one else plays. We lessor nations are eating your toast.

A lot of credit for the drop in NYC murders must go to Rudy Giuliani. He figured out that people who engage in minor crimes like jumping the turnstile on the subway tended to be the same people who committed violent crimes. At least Nanny Bloomberg didn't change that policy.

Joe,

You seem to be really upset with Justice Kagan for becoming a hunter despite her current far left record. Evidentially, she lacks the hatred toward guns that is a mark of most liberals.

I suspect you are terrified that she may drift toward the center as she gets older and finds out that Justice Scalia is not the monster the left believes.

I am not a hunter as I don't want a month's supply of moose burgers in my freezer. I support the Second Amendment because I believe a well armed population is the ultimate guarantee of liberty.

@ Clairette Rose.....

I cannot afford fine Cars, Armored safe rooms, Armed Guard's, Doberman's smarter than the average California Felon, a Rolex and sometimes even a nice steak dinner with all the trimmings served at the finest restaurant with Lobster and Caviar.....I can however afford a few firearms, training and the knowlege to safely use them.

Nobody should ever be too poor to defend themselves.
